Text: Purpose of Act
Heading: True

Text: The purpose of this Act is to—
Heading: False

Text: give effect to the constitutional right to privacy, by safeguarding personal information when processed by a responsible party, subject to justifiable limitations that are aimed at—
Heading: False

Text: balancing the right to privacy against other rights, particularly the right of access to information; and
Heading: False

Text: protecting important interests, including the free flow of information within the Republic and across international borders;
Heading: False

Text: regulate the manner in which personal information may be processed, by establishing conditions, in harmony with international standards, that prescribe the minimum threshold requirements for the lawful processing of personal information;
Heading: False

Text: provide persons with rights and remedies to protect their personal information from processing that is not in accordance with this Act; and
Heading: False

Text: establish voluntary and compulsory measures, including the establishment of an Information Regulator, to ensure respect for and to promote, enforce and fulfil the rights protected by this Act.
Heading: False

Text: Application and interpretation of Act
Heading: True

Text: This Act applies to the processing of personal information—
Heading: False

Text: entered in a record by or for a responsible party by making use of automated or non-automated means: Provided that when the recorded personal information is processed by non-automated means, it forms part of a filing system or is intended to form part thereof; and
Heading: False

Text: where the responsible party is—
Heading: False

Text: domiciled in the Republic; or
Heading: False

Text: not domiciled in the Republic, but makes use of automated or non-automated means in the Republic, unless those means are used only to forward personal information through the Republic.
Heading: False

Text: This Act applies, subject to paragraph (b), to the exclusion of any provision of any other legislation that regulates the processing of personal information and that is materially inconsistent with an object, or a specific provision, of this Act.
Heading: False

Text: If any other legislation provides for conditions for the lawful processing of personal information that are more extensive than those set out in Chapter 3, the extensive conditions prevail.
Heading: False

Text: This Act must be interpreted in a manner that—
Heading: False

Text: gives effect to the purpose of the Act set out in section 2; and
Heading: False

Text: does not prevent any public or private body from exercising or performing its powers, duties and functions in terms of the law as far as such powers, duties and functions relate to the processing of personal information and such processing is in accordance with this Act or any other legislation, as referred to in subsection (2), that regulates the processing of personal information.
Heading: False

Text: "Automated means", for the purposes of this section, means any equipment capable of operating automatically in response to instructions given for the purpose of processing information.
Heading: False

Text: Lawful processing of personal information
Heading: True

Text: The conditions for the lawful processing of personal information by or for a responsible party are the following:
Heading: False

Text: "Accountability", as referred to in section 8;
Heading: False

Text: "Processing limitation", as referred to in sections 9 to 12;
Heading: False

Text: "Purpose specification", as referred to in sections 13 and 14;
Heading: False

Text: "Further processing limitation", as referred to in section 15;
Heading: False

Text: "Information quality", as referred to in section 16;
Heading: False

Text: "Openness", as referred to in sections 17 and 18;
Heading: False

Text: "Security safeguards", as referred to in sections 19 to 22; and
Heading: False

Text: "Data subject participation", as referred to in sections 23 to 25.
Heading: False

Text: The conditions, as referred to in subsection (1), are not applicable to the processing of personal information to the extent that such processing is—
Heading: False

Text: excluded, in terms of section 6 or 7, from the operation of this Act; or
Heading: False

Text: exempted in terms of section 37 or 38, from one or more of the conditions concerned in relation to such processing.
Heading: False

Text: The processing of the special personal information of a data subject is prohibited in terms of section 26, unless the—
Heading: False

Text: provisions of sections 27 to 33 are applicable; or
Heading: False

Text: Regulator has granted an authorisation in terms of section 27(2), in which case, subject to section 37 or 38, the conditions for the lawful processing of personal information as referred to in Chapter 3 must be complied with.
Heading: False

Text: The processing of the personal information of a child is prohibited in terms of section 34, unless the—
Heading: False

Text: provisions of section 35(1) are applicable; or
Heading: False

Text: Regulator has granted an authorisation in terms of section 35(2), in which case, subject to section 37, the conditions for the lawful processing of personal information as referred to in Chapter 3 must be complied with.
Heading: False

Text: The processing of the special personal information of a child is prohibited in terms of sections 26 and 34 unless the provisions of sections 27 and 35 are applicable in whichcase, subject to section 37, the conditions for the lawful processing of personal information as referred to in Chapter 3 must be complied with.
Heading: False

Text: The conditions for the lawful processing of personal information by or for a responsible party for the purpose of direct marketing by any means are reflected in Chapter 3, read with section 69 insofar as that section relates to direct marketing by means of unsolicited electronic communications.
Heading: False

Text: Sections 60 to 68 provide for the development, in appropriate circumstances, of codes of conduct for purposes of clarifying how the conditions referred to in subsection (1), subject to any exemptions which may have been granted in terms of section 37, are to be applied, or are to be complied with within a particular sector.
Heading: False

Text: Rights of data subjects
Heading: True

Text: A data subject has the right to have his, her or its personal information processed in accordance with the conditions for the lawful processing of personal information as referred to in Chapter 3, including the right—
Heading: False

Text: to be notified that—
Heading: False

Text: personal information about him, her or it is being collected as provided for in terms of section 18; or
Heading: False

Text: his, her or its personal information has been accessed or acquired by an unauthorised person as provided for in terms of section 22;
Heading: False

Text: to establish whether a responsible party holds personal information of that data subject and to request access to his, her or its personal information as provided for in terms of section 23;
Heading: False

Text: to request, where necessary, the correction, destruction or deletion of his, her or its personal information as provided for in terms of section 24;
Heading: False

Text: to object, on reasonable grounds relating to his, her or its particular situation to the processing of his, her or its personal information as provided for in terms of section 11(3)(a);
Heading: False

Text: to object to the processing of his, her or its personal information—
Heading: False

Text: at any time for purposes of direct marketing in terms of section 11(3)(b); or
Heading: False

Text: in terms of section 69(3)(c);
Heading: False

Text: not to have his, her or its personal information processed for purposes of direct marketing by means of unsolicited electronic communications except as referred to in section 69(1);
Heading: False

Text: not to be subject, under certain circumstances, to a decision which is based solely on the basis of the automated processing of his, her or its personal information intended to provide a profile of such person as provided for in terms of section 71;
Heading: False

Text: to submit a complaint to the Regulator regarding the alleged interference with the protection of the personal information of any data subject or to submit a complaint to the Regulator in respect of a determination of an adjudicator as provided for in terms of section 74; and
Heading: False

Text: to institute civil proceedings regarding the alleged interference with the protection of his, her or its personal information as provided for in section 99.
Heading: False

Text: Exclusions
Heading: True

Text: This Act does not apply to the processing of personal information—
Heading: False

Text: in the course of a purely personal or household activity;
Heading: False

Text: that has been de-identified to the extent that it cannot be re-identified again;
Heading: False

Text: by or on behalf of a public body—
Heading: False

Text: which involves national security, including activities that are aimed at assisting in the identification of the financing of terrorist and related activities, defence or public safety; or
Heading: False

Text: the purpose of which is the prevention, detection, including assistance in the identification of the proceeds of unlawful activities and the combating of money laundering activities, investigation or proof of offences, the prosecution of offenders or the execution of sentences or security measures, to the extent that adequate safeguards have been established in legislation for the protection of such personal information;
Heading: False

Text: by the Cabinet and its committees or the Executive Council of a province; or
Heading: False

Text: relating to the judicial functions of a court referred to in section 166 of the Constitution.
Heading: False

Text: "Terrorist and related activities", for purposes of subsection (1)(c), means those activities referred to in section 4 of the Protection of Constitutional Democracy against Terrorist and Related Activities Act, 2004 (Act No. 33 of 2004).
Heading: False

Text: Exclusion for journalistic, literary or artistic purposes
Heading: True

Text: This Act does not apply to the processing of personal information solely for the purpose of journalistic, literary or artistic expression to the extent that such an exclusion is necessary to reconcile, as a matter of public interest, the right to privacy with the right to freedom of expression.
Heading: False

Text: Where a responsible party who processes personal information for exclusively journalistic purposes is, by virtue of office, employment or profession, subject to a code of ethics that provides adequate safeguards for the protection of personal information, such code will apply to the processing concerned to the exclusion of this Act and any alleged interference with the protection of the personal information of a data subject that may arise as a result of such processing must be adjudicated as provided for in terms of that code.
Heading: False

Text: In the event that a dispute may arise in respect of whether adequate safeguards have been provided for in a code as required in terms of subsection (2) or not, regard may be had to—
Heading: False

Text: the special importance of the public interest in freedom of expression;
Heading: False

Text: domestic and international standards balancing the—
Heading: False

Text: public interest in allowing for the free flow of information to the public through the media in recognition of the right of the public to be informed; and
Heading: False

Text: public interest in safeguarding the protection of personal information of data subjects;
Heading: False

Text: the need to secure the integrity of personal information;
Heading: False

Text: domestic and international standards of professional integrity for journalists; and
Heading: False

Text: the nature and ambit of self-regulatory forms of supervision provided by the profession.
Heading: False

Text: Establishment of Information Regulator
Heading: True

Text: There is hereby established a juristic person to be known as the Information Regulator, which—
Heading: False

Text: has jurisdiction throughout the Republic;
Heading: False

Text: is independent and is subject only to the Constitution and to the law and must be impartial and perform its functions and exercise its powers without fear, favour or prejudice;
Heading: False

Text: must exercise its powers and perform its functions in accordance with this Act and the Promotion of Access to Information Act; and
Heading: False

Text: is accountable to the National Assembly.
Heading: False

Text: Powers, duties and functions of Regulator
Heading: True

Text: The powers, duties and functions of the Regulator in terms of this Act are—
Heading: False

Text: to provide education by—
Heading: False

Text: promoting an understanding and acceptance of the conditions for the lawful processing of personal information and of the objects of those conditions;
Heading: False

Text: undertaking educational programmes, for the purpose of promoting the protection of personal information, on the Regulator’s own behalf or in co-operation with other persons or authorities acting on behalf of the Regulator;
Heading: False

Text: making public statements in relation to any matter affecting the protection of the personal information of a data subject or of any class of data subjects;
Heading: False

Text: giving advice to data subjects in the exercise of their rights; and
Heading: False

Text: providing advice, upon request or on its own initiative, to a Minister or a public or private body on their obligations under the provisions, and generally on any matter relevant to the operation, of this Act;
Heading: False

Text: to monitor and enforce compliance by—
Heading: False

Text: public and private bodies with the provisions of this Act;
Heading: False

Text: undertaking research into, and monitoring developments in, information processing and computer technology to ensure that any adverse effects of such developments on the protection of the personal information of data subjects are minimised, and reporting to the Minister the results of such research and monitoring;
Heading: False

Text: examining any proposed legislation, including subordinate legislation, or proposed policy of the Government that the Regulator considers mayaffect the protection of the personal information of data subjects, and reporting to the Minister the results of that examination;
Heading: False

Text: reporting upon request or on its own accord, to Parliament from time to time on any policy matter affecting the protection of the personal information of a data subject, including the need for, or desirability of, taking legislative, administrative, or other action to give protection or better protection to the personal information of a data subject;
Heading: False

Text: submitting a report to Parliament, within five months of the end of its financial year, on all its activities in terms of thisAct during that financial year;
Heading: False

Text: conducting an assessment, on its own initiative or when requested to do so, of a public or private body, in respect of the processing of personal information by that body for the purpose of ascertaining whether or not the information is processed according to the conditions for the lawful processing of personal information;
Heading: False

Text: monitoring the use of unique identifiers of data subjects, and reporting to Parliament from time to time on the results of that monitoring, including any recommendation relating to the need of, or desirability of taking, legislative, administrative, or other action to give protection, or better protection, to the personal information of a data subject;
Heading: False

Text: maintaining, publishing and making available and providing copies of such registers as are prescribed in this Act; and
Heading: False

Text: examining any proposed legislation that makes provision for the—
Heading: False

Text: collection of personal information by any public or private body; or
Heading: False

Text: disclosure of personal information by one public or private body to any other public or private body, or both, to have particular regard, in the course of that examination, to the matters set out in section 44(2), in any case where the Regulator considers that the information might be used for the purposes of an information matching programme,
Heading: False

Text: and reporting to the Minister and Parliament the results of that examination;
Heading: False

Text: to consult with interested parties by—
Heading: False

Text: receiving and inviting representations from members of the public on any matter affecting the personal information of a data subject;
Heading: False

Text: co-operating on a national and international basis with other persons and bodies concerned with the protection of personal information; and
Heading: False

Text: acting as mediator between opposing parties on any matter that concerns the need for, or the desirability of, action by a responsible party in the interests of the protection of the personal information of a data subject;
Heading: False

Text: to handle complaints by—
Heading: False

Text: receiving and investigating complaints about alleged violations of the protection of personal information of data subjects and reporting to complainants in respect of such complaints;
Heading: False

Text: gathering such information as in the Regulator’s opinion will assist the Regulator in discharging the duties and carrying out the Regulator’s functions under this Act;
Heading: False

Text: attempting to resolve complaints by means of dispute resolution mechanisms such as mediation and conciliation; and
Heading: False

Text: serving any notices in terms of this Act and further promoting the resolution of disputes in accordance with the prescripts of this Act;
Heading: False

Text: to conduct research and to report to Parliament—
Heading: False

Text: from time to time on the desirability of the acceptance, by South Africa, of any international instrument relating to the protection of the personal information of a data subject; and
Heading: False

Text: on any other matter, including necessary legislative amendments, relating to protection of personal information that, in the Regulator’s opinion, should be drawn to Parliament’s attention;
Heading: False

Text: in respect of codes of conduct to—
Heading: False

Text: issue, from time to time, codes of conduct, amend codes and to revoke codes of conduct;
Heading: False

Text: make guidelines to assist bodies to develop codes of conduct or to apply codes of conduct; and
Heading: False

Text: consider afresh, upon application, determinations by adjudicators under approved codes of conduct;
Heading: False

Text: to facilitate cross-border cooperation in the enforcement of privacy laws by participating in any initiative that is aimed at such cooperation; and
Heading: False

Heading: False

Heading: False

Heading: False

Heading: False

chapter_heading: RIGHTS OF DATA SUBJECTS REGARDING DIRECT MARKETING BY MEANS OF UNSOLICITED ELECTRONIC COMMUNICATIONS, DIRECTORIES AND AUTOMATED DECISION MAKING

Text: details of the identity of the sender or the person on whose behalf the communication has been sent; and
Heading: False
chapter_heading: RIGHTS OF DATA SUBJECTS REGARDING DIRECT MARKETING BY MEANS OF UNSOLICITED ELECTRONIC COMMUNICATIONS, DIRECTORIES AND AUTOMATED DECISION MAKING

Text: an address or other contact details to which the recipient may send a request that such communications cease.
Heading: False
chapter_heading: RIGHTS OF DATA SUBJECTS REGARDING DIRECT MARKETING BY MEANS OF UNSOLICITED ELECTRONIC COMMUNICATIONS, DIRECTORIES AND AUTOMATED DECISION MAKING

Text: "Automatic calling machine", for purposes of subsection (1), means a machine that is able to do automated calls without human intervention.
Heading: False
chapter_heading: RIGHTS OF DATA SUBJECTS REGARDING DIRECT MARKETING BY MEANS OF UNSOLICITED ELECTRONIC COMMUNICATIONS, DIRECTORIES AND AUTOMATED DECISION MAKING

Text: Directories
Heading: True
chapter_heading: RIGHTS OF DATA SUBJECTS REGARDING DIRECT MARKETING BY MEANS OF UNSOLICITED ELECTRONIC COMMUNICATIONS, DIRECTORIES AND AUTOMATED DECISION MAKING

Text: A data subject who is a subscriber to a printed or electronic directory of subscribers available to the public or obtainable through directory enquiry services, in which his, her or its personal information is included, must be informed, free of charge and before the information is included in the directory—
Heading: False
chapter_heading: RIGHTS OF DATA SUBJECTS REGARDING DIRECT MARKETING BY MEANS OF UNSOLICITED ELECTRONIC COMMUNICATIONS, DIRECTORIES AND AUTOMATED DECISION MAKING

Text: about the purpose of the directory; and
Heading: False
chapter_heading: RIGHTS OF DATA SUBJECTS REGARDING DIRECT MARKETING BY MEANS OF UNSOLICITED ELECTRONIC COMMUNICATIONS, DIRECTORIES AND AUTOMATED DECISION MAKING

Text: about any further uses to which the directory may possibly be put, based on search functions embedded in electronic versions of the directory.
Heading: False
chapter_heading: RIGHTS OF DATA SUBJECTS REGARDING DIRECT MARKETING BY MEANS OF UNSOLICITED ELECTRONIC COMMUNICATIONS, DIRECTORIES AND AUTOMATED DECISION MAKING

Text: A data subject must be given a reasonable opportunity to object, free of charge and in a manner free of unnecessary formality, to such use of his, her or its personal information or to request verification, confirmation or withdrawal of such information if the data subject has not initially refused such use.
Heading: False
chapter_heading: RIGHTS OF DATA SUBJECTS REGARDING DIRECT MARKETING BY MEANS OF UNSOLICITED ELECTRONIC COMMUNICATIONS, DIRECTORIES AND AUTOMATED DECISION MAKING

Text: Subsections (1) and (2) do not apply to editions of directories that were produced in printed or off-line electronic form prior to the commencement of this section.
Heading: False
chapter_heading: RIGHTS OF DATA SUBJECTS REGARDING DIRECT MARKETING BY MEANS OF UNSOLICITED ELECTRONIC COMMUNICATIONS, DIRECTORIES AND AUTOMATED DECISION MAKING

Text: If the personal information of data subjects who are subscribers to fixed or mobile public voice telephony services have been included in a public subscriber directory in conformity with the conditions for the lawful processing of personal information prior to the commencement of this section, the personal information of such subscribers may remain included in this public directory in its printed or electronic versions, after having received the information required by subsection (1).
Heading: False
chapter_heading: RIGHTS OF DATA SUBJECTS REGARDING DIRECT MARKETING BY MEANS OF UNSOLICITED ELECTRONIC COMMUNICATIONS, DIRECTORIES AND AUTOMATED DECISION MAKING

Text: "Subscriber", for purposes of this section, means any person who is party to a contract with the provider of publicly available electronic communications services for the supply of such services.
Heading: False
chapter_heading: RIGHTS OF DATA SUBJECTS REGARDING DIRECT MARKETING BY MEANS OF UNSOLICITED ELECTRONIC COMMUNICATIONS, DIRECTORIES AND AUTOMATED DECISION MAKING

Text: Automated decision making
Heading: True
chapter_heading: RIGHTS OF DATA SUBJECTS REGARDING DIRECT MARKETING BY MEANS OF UNSOLICITED ELECTRONIC COMMUNICATIONS, DIRECTORIES AND AUTOMATED DECISION MAKING

Text: Subject to subsection (2), a data subject may not be subject to a decision which results in legal consequences for him, her or it, or which affects him, her or it to a substantial degree, which is based solely on the basis of the automated processing of personal information intended to provide a profile of such person including his or her performance at work, or his, her or its credit worthiness, reliability, location, health, personal preferences or conduct.
Heading: False
chapter_heading: RIGHTS OF DATA SUBJECTS REGARDING DIRECT MARKETING BY MEANS OF UNSOLICITED ELECTRONIC COMMUNICATIONS, DIRECTORIES AND AUTOMATED DECISION MAKING

Text: The provisions of subsection (1) do not apply if the decision—
Heading: False
chapter_heading: RIGHTS OF DATA SUBJECTS REGARDING DIRECT MARKETING BY MEANS OF UNSOLICITED ELECTRONIC COMMUNICATIONS, DIRECTORIES AND AUTOMATED DECISION MAKING

Text: has been taken in connection with the conclusion or execution of a contract, and—
Heading: False
chapter_heading: RIGHTS OF DATA SUBJECTS REGARDING DIRECT MARKETING BY MEANS OF UNSOLICITED ELECTRONIC COMMUNICATIONS, DIRECTORIES AND AUTOMATED DECISION MAKING

Text: the request of the data subject in terms of the contract has been met; or
Heading: False
chapter_heading: RIGHTS OF DATA SUBJECTS REGARDING DIRECT MARKETING BY MEANS OF UNSOLICITED ELECTRONIC COMMUNICATIONS, DIRECTORIES AND AUTOMATED DECISION MAKING

Text: appropriate measures have been taken to protect the data subject’s legitimate interests; or
Heading: False
chapter_heading: RIGHTS OF DATA SUBJECTS REGARDING DIRECT MARKETING BY MEANS OF UNSOLICITED ELECTRONIC COMMUNICATIONS, DIRECTORIES AND AUTOMATED DECISION MAKING

Text: is governed by a law or code of conduct in which appropriate measures are specified for protecting the legitimate interests of data subjects.
Heading: False
chapter_heading: RIGHTS OF DATA SUBJECTS REGARDING DIRECT MARKETING BY MEANS OF UNSOLICITED ELECTRONIC COMMUNICATIONS, DIRECTORIES AND AUTOMATED DECISION MAKING

Text: The appropriate measures, referred to in subsection (2)(a)(ii), must—
Heading: False
chapter_heading: RIGHTS OF DATA SUBJECTS REGARDING DIRECT MARKETING BY MEANS OF UNSOLICITED ELECTRONIC COMMUNICATIONS, DIRECTORIES AND AUTOMATED DECISION MAKING

Text: provide an opportunity for a data subject to make representations about a decision referred to in subsection (1); and
Heading: False
chapter_heading: RIGHTS OF DATA SUBJECTS REGARDING DIRECT MARKETING BY MEANS OF UNSOLICITED ELECTRONIC COMMUNICATIONS, DIRECTORIES AND AUTOMATED DECISION MAKING

Text: require a responsible party to provide a data subject with sufficient information about the underlying logic of the automated processing of the information relating to him or her to enable him or her to make representations in terms of paragraph (a).
Heading: False
chapter_heading: RIGHTS OF DATA SUBJECTS REGARDING DIRECT MARKETING BY MEANS OF UNSOLICITED ELECTRONIC COMMUNICATIONS, DIRECTORIES AND AUTOMATED DECISION MAKING

Text: Transfers of personal information outside Republic
Heading: True

Text: A responsible party in the Republic may not transfer personal information about a data subject to a third party who is in a foreign country unless—
Heading: False

Text: the third party who is the recipient of the information is subject to a law, binding corporate rules or binding agreement which provide an adequate level of protection that—
Heading: False

Text: effectively upholds principles for reasonable processing of the informa- tion that are substantially similar to the conditions for the lawful processing of personal information relating to a data subject who is a natural person and, where applicable, a juristic person; and
Heading: False

Text: includes provisions, that are substantially similar to this section, relating to the further transfer of personal information from the recipient to third parties who are in a foreign country;
Heading: False

Text: the data subject consents to the transfer;
Heading: False

Text: the transfer is necessary for the performance of a contract between the data subject and the responsible party, or for the implementation of pre-contractual measures taken in response to the data subject’s request;
Heading: False

Text: the transfer is necessary for the conclusion or performance of a contract concluded in the interest of the data subject between the responsible party and a third party; or
Heading: False

Text: the transfer is for the benefit of the data subject, and—
Heading: False

Text: it is not reasonably practicable to obtain the consent of the data subject to that transfer; and
Heading: False

Text: if it were reasonably practicable to obtain such consent, the data subject would be likely to give it.
Heading: False

Text: For the purpose of this section—
Heading: False

Text: "binding corporate rules" means personal information processing policies, within a group of undertakings, which are adhered to by a responsible party or operator within that group of undertakings when transferring personal information to a responsible party or operator within that same group of undertakings in a foreign country; and
Heading: False

Text: "group of undertakings" means a controlling undertaking and its controlled undertakings.
Heading: False

Text: Interference with protection of personal information of data subject
Heading: True

Text: For the purposes of this Chapter, interference with the protection of the personal information of a data subject consists, in relation to that data subject, of—
Heading: False

Text: any breach of the conditions for the lawful processing of personal information as referred to in Chapter 3;
Heading: False

Text: non-compliance with section 22, 54, 69, 70, 71 or 72; or
Heading: False

Text: a breach of the provisions of a code of conduct issued in terms of section 60.
Heading: False

Text: Complaints
Heading: True

Text: Any person may submit a complaint to the Regulator in the prescribed manner and form alleging interference with the protection of the personal information of a data subject.
Heading: False

Text: A responsible party or data subject may, in terms of section 63(3), submit a complaint to the Regulator in the prescribed manner and form if he, she or it is aggrieved by the determination of an adjudicator.
Heading: False

Text: Mode of complaints to Regulator
Heading: True

Text: A complaint to the Regulator must be made in writing.
Heading: False

Text: The Regulator must give such reasonable assistance as is necessary in the circumstances to enable a person, who wishes to make a complaint to the Regulator, to put the complaint in writing.
Heading: False

Text: Action on receipt of complaint
Heading: True

Text: On receiving a complaint in terms of section 74, the Regulator may—
Heading: False

Text: conduct a pre-investigation as referred to in section 79;
Heading: False

Text: act, at any time during the investigation and where appropriate, as conciliator in relation to any interference with the protection of the personal information of a data subject in the prescribed manner;
Heading: False

Text: decide, in accordance with section 77, to take no action on the complaint or, as the case may be, require no further action in respect of the complaint;
Heading: False

Text: conduct a full investigation of the complaint;
Heading: False

Text: refer the complaint, in terms of section 92, to the Enforcement Committee; or
Heading: False

Text: take such further action as is contemplated by this Chapter.
Heading: False

Text: The Regulator must, as soon as is reasonably practicable, advise the complainant and the responsible party to whom the complaint relates of the course of action that the Regulator proposes to adopt under subsection (1).
Heading: False

Text: The Regulator may, on its own initiative, commence an investigation into the interference with the protection of the personal information of a data subject as referred to in section 73.
Heading: False

Text: Regulator may decide to take no action on complaint
Heading: True

Text: The Regulator, after investigating a complaint received in terms of section 73, may decide to take no action or, as the case may be, require no further action in respect of the complaint if, in the Regulator’s opinion—
Heading: False

Text: the length of time that has elapsed between the date when the subject matter of the complaint arose and the date when the complaint was made is such that an investigation of the complaint is no longer practicable or desirable;
Heading: False

Text: the subject matter of the complaint is trivial;
Heading: False

Text: the complaint is frivolous or vexatious or is not made in good faith;
Heading: False

Text: the complainant does not desire that action be taken or, as the case may be, continued;
Heading: False

Text: the complainant does not have a sufficient personal interest in the subject matter of the complaint; or
Heading: False

Text: in cases where the complaint relates to a matter in respect of which a code of conduct is in force and the code of conduct makes provision for a complaints procedure, the complainant has failed to pursue, or to pursue fully, an avenue of redress available under that complaints procedure that it would be reasonable for the complainant to pursue.
Heading: False

Text: Notwithstanding anything in subsection (1), the Regulator may in its discretion decide not to take any further action on a complaint if, in the course of the investigation of the complaint, it appears to the Regulator that, having regard to all the circumstances of the case, any further action is unnecessary or inappropriate.
Heading: False

Text: In any case where the Regulator decides to take no action, or no further action, on a complaint, the Regulator must inform the complainant of that decision and the reasons for it.
Heading: False

Text: Referral of complaint to regulatory body
Heading: True

Text: If, on receiving a complaint in terms of section 74, the Regulator considers that the complaint relates, in whole or in part, to a matter that is more properly within the jurisdiction of another regulatory body established in terms of any law, the Regulator must forthwith determine whether the complaint should be dealt with, in whole or in part, under this Act after consultation with the body concerned.
Heading: False

Text: If the Regulator determines that the complaint should be dealt with by another body, the Regulator must forthwith refer the complaint to that body to be dealt with accordingly and must notify the complainant of the referral.
Heading: False

Text: Pre-investigation proceedings of Regulator
Heading: True

Text: Before proceeding to investigate any matter in terms of this Chapter, the Regulator must, in the prescribed manner, inform—
Heading: False

Text: the complainant, the data subject to whom the investigation relates (if not the complainant) and any person alleged to be aggrieved (if not the complainant), of the Regulator’s intention to conduct the investigation; and
Heading: False

Text: the responsible party to whom the investigation relates of the—
Heading: False

Text: details of the complaint or, as the case may be, the subject matter of the investigation; and
Heading: False

Text: right of that responsible party to submit to the Regulator, within a reasonable period, a written response in relation to the complaint or, as the case may be, the subject-matter of the investigation.
Heading: False

Text: Settlement of complaints
Heading: True

Text: If it appears from a complaint, or any written response made in relation to a complaint under section 79(b)(ii), that it may be possible to secure—
Heading: False

Text: a settlement between any of the parties concerned; and
Heading: False

Text: if appropriate, a satisfactory assurance against the repetition of any action that is the subject matter of the complaint or the doing of further actions of a similar kind by the person concerned, the Regulator may, without investigating the complaint or, as the case may be, investigating the complaint further, in the prescribed manner, use its best endeavours to secure such a settlement and assurance.
Heading: False

Text: Investigation proceedings of Regulator
Heading: True

Text: For the purposes of the investigation of a complaint the Regulator may—
Heading: False

Text: summon and enforce the appearance of persons before the Regulator and compel them to give oral or written evidence on oath and to produce any records and things that the Regulator considers necessary to investigate the complaint, in the same manner and to the same extent as the High Court;
Heading: False

Text: administer oaths;
Heading: False

Text: receive and accept any evidence and other information, whether on oath, by affidavit or otherwise, that the Regulator sees fit, whether or not it is or would be admissible in a court of law;
Heading: False

Text: at any reasonable time, subject to section 81, enter and search any premises occupied by a responsible party;
Heading: False

Text: conduct a private interview with any person in any premises entered under section 84 subject to section 82; and
Heading: False

Text: otherwise carry out in those premises any inquiries that the Regulator sees fit in terms of section 82.
Heading: False

Text: Issue of warrants
Heading: True

Text: A judge of the High Court, a regional magistrate or a magistrate, if satisfied by information on oath supplied by the Regulator that there are reasonable grounds for suspecting that—
Heading: False

Text: a responsible party is interfering with the protection of the personal information of a data subject; or
Heading: False

Text: an offence under this Act has been or is being committed, and that evidence of the contravention or of the commission of the offence is to be found on any premises specified in the information, that are within the jurisdiction of that judge or magistrate, may, subject to subsection (2), grant a warrant to enter and search such premises.
Heading: False

Text: A warrant issued under subsection (1) authorises any of the Regulator’s members or staff members, subject to section 84, at any time within seven days of the date of the warrant to enter the premises as identified in the warrant, to search them, to inspect, examine, operate and test any equipment found there which is used or intended to beused for the processing of personal information and to inspect and seize any record, other material or equipment found there which may be such evidence as is mentioned in that subsection.
Heading: False

Text: Requirements for issuing of warrant
Heading: True

Text: A judge or magistrate must not issue a warrant under section 82 unless satisfied that—
Heading: False

Text: the Regulator has given seven days’ notice in writing to the occupier of the premises in question demanding access to the premises;
Heading: False

Text: either—
Heading: False

Text: access was demanded at a reasonable hour and was unreasonably refused; or
Heading: False

Text: although entry to the premises was granted, the occupier unreasonably refused to comply with a request by any of the Regulator’s members or staff to permit the members or the members of staff to do any of the things referred to in section 82(2); and
Heading: False

Text: that the occupier, has, after the refusal, been notified by the Regulator of the application for the warrant and has had an opportunity of being heard on the question whether the warrant should be issued.
Heading: False

Text: Subsection (1) does not apply if the judge or magistrate is satisfied that the case is one of urgency or that compliance with that subsection would defeat the object of the entry.
Heading: False

Text: A judge or magistrate who issues a warrant under section 82 must also issue two copies of it and certify them clearly as copies.
Heading: False

Text: Execution of warrants
Heading: True

Text: A police officer who is assisting a person authorised to conduct an entry and search in terms of a warrant issued under section 82 may overcome resistance to the entry and search by using such force as is reasonably necessary.
Heading: False

Text: A warrant issued under this section must be executed at a reasonable hour unless it appears to the person executing it that there are reasonable grounds for suspecting that the evidence in question would not be found if it were so executed.
Heading: False

Text: If the person who occupies the premises in respect of which a warrant is issued under section 82 is present when the warrant is executed, he or she must be shown the warrant and supplied with a copy of it, and if that person is not present a copy of the warrant must be left in a prominent place on the premises.
Heading: False

Text: A person seizing anything in pursuance of a warrant under section 82 must give a receipt to the occupier or leave the receipt on the premises.
Heading: False

Text: nything so seized may be retained for as long as is necessary in all circumstances but the person in occupation of the premises in question must be given a copy of any documentation that is seized if he or she so requests and the person executing the warrant considers that it can be done without undue delay.
Heading: False

Text: A person authorised to conduct an entry and search in terms of section 82 must be accompanied and assisted by a police officer.
Heading: False

Text: A person who enters and searches any premises under this section must conduct the entry and search with strict regard for decency and order, and with regard to each person’s right to dignity, freedom, security and privacy.
Heading: False

Text: A person who enters and searches premises under this section must before questioning any person—
Heading: False

Text: advise that person of the right to be assisted at the time by an advocate or attorney; and
Heading: False

Text: allow that person to exercise that right.
Heading: False

Text: No self-incriminating answer given or statement made to a person who conducts a search in terms of a warrant issued under section 82 is admissible as evidence against the person who gave the answer or made the statement in criminal proceedings, except in criminal proceedings for perjury or in which that person is tried for an offencecontemplated in section 102 and then only to the extent that the answer or statement is relevant to prove the offence charged.
Heading: False

Text: Matters exempt from search and seizure
Heading: True

Text: If the Regulator has granted an exemption in terms of section 37, the information that is processed in terms of that exemption is not subject to search and seizure empowered by a warrant issued under section 82.
Heading: False

Text: Communication between legal adviser and client exempt
Heading: True

Text: Subject to the provisions of this section, the powers of search and seizure conferred by a warrant issued under section 82 must not be exercised in respect of—
Heading: False

Text: any communication between a professional legal adviser and his or her client in connection with the giving of legal advice to the client with respect to his or her obligations, liabilities or rights; or
Heading: False

Text: any communication between a professional legal adviser and his or her client, or between such an adviser or his or her client and any other person, made in connection with or in contemplation of proceedings under or arising out of this Act, including proceedings before a court, and for the purposes of such proceedings.
Heading: False

Text: Subsection (1) applies also to—
Heading: False

Text: any copy or other record of any such communication as is mentioned therein; and
Heading: False

Text: any document or article enclosed with or referred to in any such communication if made in connection with the giving of any advice or, as the case may be, in connection with or in contemplation of and for the purposes of such proceedings as are mentioned therein.
Heading: False

Text: Objection to search and seizure
Heading: True

Text: If the person in occupation of any premises in respect of which a warrant is issued under this Act objects to the inspection or seizure under the warrant of any material on the ground that it—
Heading: False

Text: contains privileged information and refuses the inspection or removal of such article or document, the person executing the warrant or search must, if he or she is of the opinion that the article or document contains information that has a bearing on the investigation and that such information is necessary for the investigation, request the Registrar of the High Court which has jurisdiction or his or her delegate, to attach and remove that article or document for safe custody until a court of law has made a ruling on the question whether the information concerned is privileged or not; or
Heading: False

Text: consists partly of matters in respect of which those powers are not exercised, he or she must, if the person executing the warrant so requests, furnish that person with a copy of so much of the material as is not exempt from those powers.
Heading: False

Text: Return of warrants
Heading: True

Text: A warrant issued under section 82 must be returned to the court from which it was issued—
Heading: False

Text: after being executed; or
Heading: False

Text: if not executed within the time authorised for its execution, and the person who has executed the warrant must make an endorsement on it stating what powers have been exercised by him or her under the warrant.
Heading: False

Text: Assessment
Heading: True

Text: The Regulator, on its own initiative, or at the request by or on behalf of the responsible party, data subject or any other person must make an assessment in the prescribed manner of whether an instance of processing of personal information complies with the provisions of this Act.
Heading: False

Text: The Regulator must make the assessment if it appears to be appropriate, unless, where the assessment is made on request, the Regulator has not been supplied with such information as it may reasonably require in order to—
Heading: False

Text: satisfy itself as to the identity of the person making the request; and
Heading: False

Text: enable it to identify the action in question.
Heading: False

Text: The matters to which the Regulator may have regard in determining whether it is appropriate to make an assessment include—
Heading: False

Text: the extent to which the request appears to it to raise a matter of substance;
Heading: False

Text: any undue delay in making the request; and
Heading: False

Text: whether or not the person making the request is entitled to make an application in terms of section 23 or 24 in respect of the personal information in question.
Heading: False

Text: If the Regulator has received a request under this section it must notify the requester—
Heading: False

Text: whether it has made an assessment as a result of the request; and
Heading: False

Text: to the extent that it considers appropriate, having regard in particular to any exemption which has been granted by the Regulator in terms of section 37 from section 23 or 24 applying in relation to the personal information concerned, of any view formed or action taken as a result of the request.
Heading: False

Text: Information notice
Heading: True

Text: If the Regulator—
Heading: False

Text: has received a request under section 89 in respect of any processing of personal information; or
Heading: False

Text: reasonably requires any information for the purpose of determining whether the responsible party has interfered or is interfering with the personal information of a data subject, the Regulator may serve the responsible party with an information notice requiring the responsible party to furnish the Regulator, within a specified period, in a form specified in the notice, with a report indicating that the processing is taking place in compliance with the provisions of the Act, or with such information relating to the request or to compliance with the Act as is so specified.
Heading: False

Text: An information notice must contain particulars of the right of appeal conferred by section 97, and—
Heading: False

Text: in a case falling within subsection (1)(a), a statement that the Regulator has received a request under section 89 in relation to the specified processing; or
Heading: False

Text: in a case falling within subsection (1)(b), a statement that the Regulator regards the specified information as relevant for the purpose of determining whether the responsible party has complied, or is complying, with the conditions for the lawful processing of personal information and the reasons for regarding it as relevant for that purpose.
Heading: False

Text: Subject to subsection (5), the period specified in an information notice must not expire before the end of the period within which an appeal can be brought against the notice and, if such an appeal is brought, the information need not be furnished pending the determination or withdrawal of the appeal.
Heading: False

Text: If the Regulator considers that the information is required as a matter of urgency, it may include in the notice a statement to that effect and a statement of its reasons for reaching that conclusion, and in that event subsection (3) does not apply.
Heading: False

Text: A notice in terms of subsection (4) may not require the information to be furnished before the end of a period of three days beginning with the day on which the notice is served.
Heading: False

Text: An information notice may not require a responsible party to furnish the Regulator with any communication between a—
Heading: False

Text: professional legal adviser and his or her client in connection with the giving of legal advice on the client’s obligations, liabilities or rights under this Act; or
Heading: False

Text: professional legal adviser and his or her client, or between such an adviser or his or her client and any other person, made in connection with or in contemplation of proceedings under or arising out of this Act (including proceedings before a court) and for the purposes of such proceedings.
Heading: False

Text: In subsection (6) references to the client of a professional legal adviser include any person representing such a client.
Heading: False

Text: An information notice may not require a responsible party to furnish the Regulator with information that would, by revealing evidence of the commission of any offence other than an offence under this Act, expose the responsible party to criminal proceedings.
Heading: False

Text: The Regulator may cancel an information notice by written notice to the responsible party on whom it was served.
Heading: False

Text: Parties to be informed of result of assessment
Heading: True

Text: After completing the assessment referred to in section 89 the Regulator—
Heading: False

Text: must report to the responsible party the results of the assessment and any recommendations that the Regulator considers appropriate; and
Heading: False

Text: may, in appropriate cases, require the responsible party, within a specified time, to inform the Regulator of any action taken or proposed to be taken to implement the recommendations contained in the report or reasons why no such action has been or is proposed to be taken.
Heading: False

Text: The Regulator may make public any information relating to the personal information management practices of a responsible party that has been the subject of an assessment under this section if the Regulator considers it in the public interest to do so.
Heading: False

Text: A report made by the Regulator under subsection (1) is deemed to be the equivalent of an enforcement notice in terms of section 95.
Heading: False

Text: Matters referred to Enforcement Committee
Heading: True

Text: After completing the investigation of a complaint or other matter in terms of this Act, the Regulator may refer such complaint or other matter to the Enforcement Committee for consideration, a finding in respect of the complaint or other matter and a recommendation in respect of the proposed action to be taken by the Regulator as referred to in section 93.
Heading: False

Text: The Regulator may prescribe the procedure to be followed by the Enforcement Committee, including—
Heading: False

Text: the manner in which the responsible party and data subject may make submissions to the Enforcement Committee;
Heading: False

Text: the opportunity afforded to the parties who make submissions to the Enforcement Committee to make use of legal or other representation;
Heading: False

Text: the period within which the Enforcement Committee must make a finding and submit its recommendation to the Regulator in respect of the complaint or other matter; and
Heading: False

Text: the manner in which the Enforcement Committee may finalise urgent matters.
Heading: False

Text: Functions of Enforcement Committee
Heading: True

Text: The Enforcement Committee—
Heading: False

Text: must consider all matters referred to it by the Regulator in terms of section 92 or the Promotion of Access to Information Act and make a finding in respect thereof; and
Heading: False

Text: may make any recommendation to the Regulator necessary or incidental to any action that should be taken against—
Heading: False

Text: a responsible party in terms of this Act; or
Heading: False

Text: an information officer or head of a private body, as the case may be, in terms of the Promotion of Access to Information Act.
Heading: False

Text: Parties to be informed of developments during and result of investigation
Heading: True

Text: If an investigation is made following a complaint, and—
Heading: False

Text: the Regulator believes that no interference with the protection of the personal information of a data subject has taken place and therefore does not serve an enforcement notice;
Heading: False

Text: the Regulator has referred the complaint to the Enforcement Committee for consideration in terms of section 92;
Heading: False

Text: an enforcement notice is served in terms of section 95;
Heading: False

Text: a served enforcement notice is cancelled in terms of section 96;
Heading: False

Text: an appeal is lodged against the enforcement notice for cancellation or variation of the notice in terms of section 97; or
Heading: False

Text: an appeal against an enforcement notice is allowed, the notice is substituted or the appeal is dismissed in terms of section 98, the Regulator must inform the complainant and the responsible party, as soon as reasonably practicable, in the manner prescribed of any development mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (f) and the result of the investigation.
Heading: False

Text: Enforcement notice
Heading: True

Text: If the Regulator, after having considered the recommendation of the Enforcement Committee in terms of section 93, is satisfied that a responsible party has interfered or is interfering with the protection of the personal information of a data subject as referred to in section 73, the Regulator may serve the responsible party with an enforcement notice requiring the responsible party to do either or both of the following:
Heading: False

Text: To take specified steps within a period specified in the notice, or to refrain from taking such steps; or
Heading: False

Text: to stop processing personal information specified in the notice, or to stop processing personal information for a purpose or in a manner specified in the notice within a period specified in the notice.
Heading: False

Text: An enforcement notice must contain—
Heading: False

Text: a statement indicating the nature of the interference with the protection of the personal information of the data subject and the reasons for reaching that conclusion; and
Heading: False

Text: particulars of the rights of appeal conferred by section 97.
Heading: False

Text: Subject to subsection (4), an enforcement notice may not require any of the provisions of the notice to be complied with before the end of the period within which an appeal may be brought against the notice and, if such an appeal is brought, the notice need not be complied with pending the determination or withdrawal of the appeal.
Heading: False

Text: If the Regulator considers that an enforcement notice should be complied with as a matter of urgency it may include in the notice a statement to that effect and a statement of its reasons for reaching that conclusion, and in that event subsection (3) does not apply.
Heading: False

Text: A notice in terms of subsection (4) may not require any of the provisions of the notice to be complied with before the end of a period of three days beginning with the day on which the notice is served.
Heading: False

Text: Cancellation of enforcement notice
Heading: True

Text: A responsible party on whom an enforcement notice has been served may, at any time after the expiry of the period during which an appeal may be brought against that notice, apply in writing to the Regulator for the cancellation or variation of that notice on the ground that, by reason of a change of circumstances, all or any of the provisions of that notice need not be complied with in order to ensure compliance with the conditions for the lawful processing of personal information.
Heading: False

Text: If the Regulator considers that all or any of the provisions of an enforcement notice need not be complied with in order to ensure compliance with a condition for the lawful processing of personal information or conditions to which it relates, it may cancel or vary the notice by written notice to the responsible party on whom it was served.
Heading: False

Text: Right of appeal
Heading: True

Text: A responsible party on whom an information or enforcement notice has been served may, within 30 days of receiving the notice, appeal to the High Court having jurisdiction for the setting aside or variation of the notice.
Heading: False

Text: A complainant, who has been informed of the result of the investigation in terms of section 77(3) or 96, may, within 180 days of receiving the result, appeal to the High Court having jurisdiction against the result.

Heading: True

Text: If in an appeal under section 97 the court considers—

Text: that the notice or decision against which the appeal is brought is not in accordance with the law; or
Heading: False

Text: that the notice or decision involved an exercise of discretion by the Regulator that ought to have been exercised differently, the court must allow the appeal and may set aside the notice or substitute such other notice or decision as should have been served or made by the Regulator.
Heading: False

Text: In such an appeal, the court may review any determination of fact on which the notice in question was based.
Heading: False

Heading: True

Text: A data subject or, at the request of the data subject, the Regulator, may institute a civil action for damages in a court having jurisdiction against a responsible party for breach of any provision of this Act as referred to in section 73, whether or not there is intent or negligence on the part of the responsible party.

Text: In the event of a breach the responsible party may raise any of the following defences against an action for damages:

Text: Vis major;
Heading: False

Text: consent of the plaintiff;
Heading: False

Text: fault on the part of the plaintiff;
Heading: False

Text: compliance was not reasonably practicable in the circumstances of the particular case; or
Heading: False

Text: the Regulator has granted an exemption in terms of section 37.
Heading: False

Text: A court hearing proceedings in terms of subsection (1) may award an amount that is just and equitable, including—
Heading: False

Text: payment of damages as compensation for patrimonial and non-patrimonial loss suffered by a data subject as a result of breach of the provisions of this Act;
Heading: False

Text: aggravated damages, in a sum determined in the discretion of the Court;
Heading: False

Text: interest; and
Heading: False

Text: costs of suit on such scale as may be determined by the Court.
Heading: False

Text: Any amount awarded to the Regulator in terms of subsection (3) must be dealt with in the following manner:
Heading: False

Text: The full amount must be deposited into a specifically designated trust account established by the Regulator with an appropriate financial institution;
Heading: False

Text: as a first charge against the amount, the Regulator may recover all reasonable expenses incurred in bringing proceedings at the request of a data subject in terms of subsection (1) and in administering the distributions made to the data subject in terms of subsection (5); and
Heading: False

Text: the balance, if any (in this section referred to as the "distributable balance"), must be distributed by the Regulator to the data subject at whose request the proceedings were brought.
Heading: False

Text: ny amount not distributed within three years from the date of the first distribution of payments in terms of subsection (4), accrue to the Regulator in the Regulator’s official capacity.
Heading: False

Text: The distributable balance must be distributed on a pro rata basis to the data subject referred to in subsection (1).
Heading: False

Text: A Court issuing any order under this section must order it to be published in the Gazette and by such other appropriate public media announcement as the Court considers appropriate.
Heading: False

Text: Any civil action instituted under this section may be withdrawn, abandoned or compromised, but any agreement or compromise must be made an order of Court.
Heading: False

Text: If a civil action has not been instituted, any agreement or settlement, if any, may, on application to the Court by the Regulator after due notice to the other party, be made an order of Court and must be published in the Gazette and by such other public media announcement as the Court considers appropriate.

Heading: False

Heading: False

Heading: False

Text: Unlawful acts by responsible party in connection with account number
Heading: True

Text: A responsible party who contravenes the provisions of section 8 insofar as those provisions relate to the processing of an account number of a data subject is, subject to subsections (2) and (3), guilty of an offence.

Heading: False

Text: likely cause substantial damage or distress to the data subject.

Heading: False

Heading: False

Text: there was a risk that the contravention would occur; or
Heading: False

Text: such contravention would likely cause substantial damage or distress to the data subject; and
Heading: False

Text: have failed to take reasonable steps to prevent the contravention.
Heading: False

Heading: False

Heading: False

Heading: False

Text: Unlawful acts by third parties in connection with account number
Heading: True

Text: A person who knowingly or recklessly, without the consent of the responsible party—
Heading: False

Text: obtains or discloses an account number of a data subject; or
Heading: False

Text: procures the disclosure of an account number of a data subject to another person, is, subject to subsection (2), guilty of an offence.

Heading: False

Text: the obtaining, disclosure or procuring of the account number was—

Heading: False

Text: required or authorised in terms of the law or in terms of a court order;

Text: Administrative fines
Heading: True

Text: If a responsible party is alleged to have committed an offence in terms of this Act, the Regulator may cause to be delivered by hand to that person (hereinafter referred to as the infringer) an infringement notice which must contain the particulars contemplated in subsection (2).

Heading: False

Heading: False

Heading: False

Heading: False

Heading: False

Text: The Regulator may not impose an administrative fine contemplated in this section if the responsible party concerned has been charged with an offence in terms of this Act in respect of the same set of facts.
